definition:
A ring is said to be *semiprimitive* if its Jacobson radical is the zero
ideal.

Any simple ring is automatically semiprimitive.

A finite direct product of matrix rings over division rings can be shown
to be semiprimitive and both left and right Artinian.

The states that any semiprimitive ring which is left or right Artinian
is isomorphic to a finite direct product of matrix rings over division
rings.

[**Note**]{}: The semiprimitive condition is sometimes also referred to
as a *semisimple*, *Jacobson semisimple*, or *J-semisimple*.
Furthermore, when either of the last two names are used, the adjective
’semisimple’ is frequently intended to refer to a ring that is
semiprimitive and Artinian (see the entry on ).
